entry.title: jdk 10/11 local variable type inference
entry.content:
Official documentation
Style guidelines

This lesson includes local variable type inference from JDK 10 and local variable syntax for lambda parameters (JDK 11). Reserved type name ‘var’ was introduced to be used instead of the explicit type declaration, where type can be deduced.

How to use ‘var’?

1) local variable declarations with initializer;

2) enhanced for-loop

3) traditional for-loop

4) try with resources

5) with anonymous classes

6) casting lambda expressions to intersection types

How to not use ‘var’?

1) var cannot be used in catch clauses

2) var not allowed for method type declaration

3) var cannot be used to define constructor arguments type

4) var cannot be used as a method return type

5) var not allowed to be used as a field type

6) var not allowed as a target type of lambda expression

7) null cannot be assigned to var

8) var cannot be used with array initializer

‘var’ is not a keyword, it is reserved type name, hence:

1) you can use var as a variable name. you cannot do it with keywords.

2) you can use it as a package name;

3) you can use it as a method name

4) we cannot create a class name with a name var

5) we cannot name interface as ‘var’

Java 11

Java 11 allows using var in lambda expressions.

  1. (var x, var y) -> x + “-“ + y … is the same as … (x, y) -> x + “-“ + y
  2. This change is a further enhancement of var usage in java, that was introduced in jdk 10.
  3. var allows us usage of annotations (@NotNull for example).
  4. var cannot be mixed with no var.
  5. var cannot be mixed with explicitly typed parameters (e.i. int)
  6. var should be used for all lambda formal parameters not be used at all.

lombok alternative: ‘var’ and ‘val’

Explicit import required:

Pitfalls

Be careful using var with diamonds <>. Type inference for generic methods relies on the target type (what on the left of ‘=’). For ‘var inferredQueue’ inferred type is PriorityQueue

It is a common practice in java to construct a concrete instance and assign it to an interface type. If ‘var’ is used, the inferred type is a concrete instance, instead of an interface.

With a numeric type on the left, a type might be widened or narrowed to types other than int. With ‘var’ type is always int.
entry.summary: Reserved type name 'var' was introduced to be used instead of explicit type declaration, where type can be deduced...

entry.title: java 13/14 text blocks
entry.content:
Check out the Official documentation

Text blocks were released in jdk 13, and improved in jdk 14 with new escape sequences

JDK 13

The text blocks improve code readability. No escaping, newline, or tabs characters appear in the string. “”” was chosen so that “ character could appear unescaped inside text blocks.

The code should be in a new line after opening fat delimiters (three double-quote characters). No newline character will be added after compilation. Check out the compiled class. The closing””” can appear after the last character. If you do not want to have \n character at the end, add a closing “”” after your code.

\" - the use of escaping character permitted, but not necessary.

\n - line terminator permitted, but not necessary.

Text block can be empty, but it is not recommended as it takes 2 lines of source code.

Whitespace surrounding the content is generally() removed during compilation. Check out the compiled class. () - check out the next stringWithSpace string example.

But if closing fat delimiters (“””) have no leading space at all, space remains. That happens because of the peculiarity of the re-identation algorithm, that calculates how much leading space should be removed. It calculates the number of whitespace characters for every non-blank line and removes from every line the least number of whitespace.

Text blocks are indistinguishable from string literals after compilation. Check out the compiled code.

CR or CRLF line separators are turned into LF line separators. If you explicitly add escaped CR line separator it will remain with LF at the end. This ensures that the code is the same across the platforms. Check out the compiled code.

New String::formatted(Object... args) method has been added in jdk 13, that simplifies value substitution in text blocks.

String literals can be concatenated with text blocks.

JDK 14

Sometimes long lines are broken into smaller lines with “+”, but it remains one line.

To maintain one-line strings in text blocks, new escape line terminator (“") has been added to java 14. A new escape line terminator can only be used with the text blocks. Check out the compiled code.

In jdk 14 single space escape sequence has been introduced (“\s”).

Single space escape sequences can be used in string literals as well.

entry.title: java enhanced switch statements and switch expressions

link.title: java enhanced switch statements and switch expressions

entry.content:
Check out the Official documentation

What is the problem with the existing switch statements? Problem #1: they are error-prone. A developer might forget to add a break statement. This will lead to an unexpected result. Try to call this method with “lynca mobile” input.

Enhanced switch statements were introduced.vOnly expressions on the right of -> will be executed. This solved problem #1 mentioned above.

What is the problem with the existing switch statements? Problem #2: variable defined inside one arm has a scope of an entire block. Another arm/case cannot use the same variable name.

Enhanced switch statements solve problem #2 mentioned above. A variable inside one arm has a scope of this arm.

Switch expression example. A default case is required if the enum is not used in a case. For enum, example look at printNameAssociatedWithId(Numbers) method below.

Switch expression can be passed and argument to methods.

Jdk 14 introduced the ‘yield’ statement to return value. ‘yield’ is a restricted identifier and no class can be named that way. Switch expression must either produce value or throw an exception. If you try to comment yield statement compiler will complain.

Switch expression can use a traditional representation with colon label “:”.

Interesting case

The default case is not required in case of the enum (if we cover all cases). If omitted it will be added by the compiler. It is not even recommended to add default case, to throw an exception to indicate unexpected value.

entry.title: java 14 records
entry.content:
Check out the Official documentation

We can create a class with instance fields, constructor, toString(), hashCode(), equals() and getters. That requires a lot of boilerplate code:

In jdk 14 we can have the same result with records.

The record can be without components (arguments).

Instance fields are not allowed in records. Even if we try, no setter will be generated as records supposed to be shallowly immutable.

A record can have static fields, static and instance methods.

Records can have a compact constructor with no parameters. When we use a compact constructor we do not need to assign input parameters to private members. Record’s generated methods can be overridden (ctrl + o in Intellij).

We can also generate a canonical constructor. Canonical constructor has all parameters. Initialization of fields required. alt + Insert for generation in Intellij.

Records have a custom constructor, that is not required to have all parameters, but has to call a canonical constructor.

Records can be generic. We can create record the same way as a class:
Shape<Triangle> triangleShape = new Shape<>(new Triangle());

Nested records are declared static.

New methods has been added to the Class to support new Record type:

  • isRecord() and
  • getRecordComponents().

A tuple is a collection of elements of different (not necessarily the same) type. Tuples are an alternative to java records. Java records have a few advantages over tuples:

  • records have meaningful class and members names;
  • a class can support state validation in their constructor.

entry.title: java 14 pattern matching
entry.content:
Check out the Official documentation.

Now we can create the person variable through pattern matching. If x is instanceof String, then the person variable will be created.

Pattern matching can be also used to write one line checks. If x is an instance of User, the user variable is created and the address returned.

If on the left of && condition we create a pattern variable, then this variable can be also used on the right.

Pattern variable cannot be used on the right of || because it means that x is not an instance of String if the second condition is checked.

What variable will be printed: parameter or the class static member variable if true?
